nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"ok -> i will explain you the current state of the project: 1. demuxing and decoding videoframes while recording causes recording to glitch 2. i don't like how we handled auto-resolver -> we need to reconsider how we compile a possibly complexly nested graph of tracks and groups and clips into an easy queryable datastructure so we don't have to calculate anything during scrubbing 3. when demuxing and decoding more then 3 videos jank starts to appear 4. there is the idea of doing pre-rendering and compositing this with the preview, but that would prevent us from rendering atop of the grid (currently not implemented: everything is in a grid for the MVP, but for future consideration) 4. we had implemented preview rendering at some point, but i decided to remove it during a previous simplification of the library. 5. for the mvp we also want to be able to record over the same track in a later offset -> and loop 6. but before we implement we have to focus first on the performance aspect -> if we can not play it smoothly and record at the same time the project is doomed -> formalize this in a series of issues and let's add them to remote"}

nodes.title: Created 5 GitHub issues with prioritization
How to handle demuxing/decoding performance for smooth playback + recording
Option A: Pause decode during recording
Option B: Pre-decode all frames to memory before playback
Option C: Lower decode priority/quality during recording
Option D: Use different codec/format more suited for editing (ProRes-like)
Option E: Offload decode to GPU via WebGPU/WebGL
How to measure/profile performance bottlenecks
Option A: Chrome DevTools Performance tab + screenshot
Option B: User Timing API (performance.mark/measure) + export
Option C: stats.js (FPS/MS/MB overlay)
Option D: PerformanceObserver + structured JSON export
Option E: Playwright + CDP tracing (automated, headless)
Scaffold Playwright performance testing workflow
Existing perf infrastructure found: scripts/perf-test.ts + @eddy/utils/perf
Committed: fix SolidJS store mutation bug and type errors
Committed: add perf instrumentation to playback workers
Baseline perf: 4-track VP9 decode ~6ms/frame/track, bufferAhead spikes to 76ms on keyframes
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Performance test results (4-track VP9 playback, 10s duration):

MAIN THREAD:
- renderLoop: 0.05ms avg, 0.18ms max, 0% slow frames
- Effective FPS: ~18595 (loop overhead only, work offloaded to workers)

PER-TRACK WORKER STATS (all 4 tracks similar):
- bufferAhead: ~7ms avg, 76ms max, ~2.5% slow
- decode: ~6ms avg, 28ms max, ~1% slow
- transferFrame: ~0.25ms avg, ~2ms max, 0% slow
- demux: ~0.05ms avg, <1ms max, 0% slow

KEY FINDINGS:
1. Decode is the bottleneck (~6ms per frame per track)
2. 4 tracks * 6ms = 24ms total decode time (exceeds 16.67ms frame budget for 60fps)
3. bufferAhead spikes to 76ms occasionally (keyframe decode)
4. Main thread is very fast - worker architecture is effective
5. No dropped frames in test (buffering ahead compensates)

IMPLICATIONS FOR DECISION #34 (demux/decode performance):
- Current approach works for pure playback
- Recording + playback would add ~10-20ms per frame for muxing
- Options B (pre-decode) or C (lower priority during record) most promising"}

2. Different encoding parameters in test files

Updated perf-test.ts to default to test-vp9.webm"}

nodes.title: Option F: SharedArrayBuffer priority coordinator - lock-free cross-worker priority signaling
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"SharedArrayBuffer-based priority coordination:

MECHANISM:
- Central SharedArrayBuffer shared across all workers
- Atomic flags: RECORDING_ACTIVE, DECODE_PRIORITY (0=low, 1=normal, 2=high)
- Recording worker sets RECORDING_ACTIVE=1, DECODE_PRIORITY=0
- Playback workers check priority before each decode operation
- When priority=low: skip non-keyframes, reduce buffer-ahead

PROS:
- Lock-free (uses Atomics.load/store)
- Very low overhead (~nanoseconds to check)
- Already using this pattern for audio ring buffer
- True cross-worker synchronization

CONS:
- Requires SharedArrayBuffer (needs COOP/COEP headers)
- Manual priority logic in each worker
- No browser-level scheduling integration

IMPLEMENTATION SKETCH:
```ts
// Priority coordinator (shared)
const RECORDING_ACTIVE = 0
const DECODE_PRIORITY = 1
const coord = new Int32Array(new SharedArrayBuffer(8))

// Recording worker
Atomics.store(coord, RECORDING_ACTIVE, 1)
Atomics.store(coord, DECODE_PRIORITY, 0) // low

// Playback worker - before decode
if (Atomics.load(coord, RECORDING_ACTIVE) && !sample.isKeyframe) {
  return // skip non-keyframe during recording
}
```"}

nodes.title: Option G: Scheduler API (scheduler.postTask) - browser-native priority scheduling
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":75,"prompt":"Browser's Scheduler API for priority-based task scheduling:

MECHANISM:
- Use scheduler.postTask() with priority hints
- Recording: 'user-blocking' (highest priority)
- Playback decode: 'user-visible' normally, 'background' during recording
- Browser scheduler handles thread contention intelligently

PROS:
- Browser-native, well-optimized
- Integrates with browser's rendering pipeline
- No manual coordination needed
- Works across workers

CONS:
- Relatively new API (Chrome 94+, no Firefox/Safari)
- Less granular control than manual approach
- Can't guarantee frame timing
- Polyfill needed for unsupported browsers

IMPLEMENTATION SKETCH:
```ts
// Recording - highest priority
await scheduler.postTask(() => muxFrame(frame), { priority: 'user-blocking' })

// Playback - yield to recording
await scheduler.postTask(() => decodeFrame(sample), { 
  priority: isRecording ? 'background' : 'user-visible' 
})

// Or use scheduler.yield() to let higher priority run
for (const sample of samples) {
  await scheduler.yield()
  decode(sample)
}
```"}

nodes.title: Option H: Backpressure + adaptive quality - workers signal load, coordinator throttles
Option I: Hybrid - SharedArrayBuffer flags + RPC backpressure + adaptive decode
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Hybrid approach combining multiple mechanisms:

LAYER 1: SharedArrayBuffer (immediate coordination)
- Atomic RECORDING_ACTIVE flag
- Playback workers check before EVERY decode
- Zero-latency priority signal

LAYER 2: RPC backpressure (adaptive tuning)
- Recording worker reports mux time via RPC
- If mux time > threshold: playback reduces aggressively
- Smooth adaptation vs binary on/off

LAYER 3: Adaptive decode strategies
- Skip non-keyframes when recording
- Reduce buffer-ahead (30 → 5 frames)
- Accept stale frames (show last good frame)

PRIORITY GUARANTEE:
Recording: ALWAYS mux every frame (perfect capture)
Playback: Best-effort, graceful degradation

WHY HYBRID:
- SharedArrayBuffer: instant signaling, no async overhead
- RPC: rich metadata, tunable thresholds
- Adaptive: smooth user experience during recording

IMPLEMENTATION:
```ts
// Shared control
const ctrl = new Int32Array(sharedBuffer)
const RECORDING = 0

// Recording starts
Atomics.store(ctrl, RECORDING, 1)
notifyPlaybackWorkers({ mode: 'recording', muxBudget: 10 })

// Playback worker decode loop
if (Atomics.load(ctrl, RECORDING) && !sample.isKeyframe) {
  continue // instant skip
}
await decode(sample)
```"}

nodes.title: scheduler.postTask NOT suitable for frame timing - only for task prioritization
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Clarification on Option G (Scheduler API):

NOT SUITABLE FOR:
- Frame rendering timing (needs vsync alignment)
- Precise timing guarantees (browser decides when)
- Real-time frame delivery

ONLY USEFUL FOR:
- Prioritizing decode work vs mux work
- Hinting "this task more important than that"
- Background work deferral

ACTUAL FRAME RENDERING NEEDS:
- requestAnimationFrame for display timing (vsync-aligned)
- VideoFrame API for compositor delivery
- SharedArrayBuffer for instant cross-worker signaling

CONCLUSION:
Option G is a "nice to have" for background work scheduling, but NOT a solution for the core frame timing problem. Options F (SharedArrayBuffer) and H (backpressure) are the real solutions.

Downgrade Option G from "solution" to "supplementary optimization"."}

nodes.title: Which edit-friendly codec/format to use for fast seeking and decode?
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Sub-decision under Option D (node 38).

Requirements for edit-friendly codec:
1. All keyframes (intra-frame only) - instant seeking
2. Fast decode - ideally hardware accelerated  
3. WebCodecs support - must work in browser
4. Reasonable file size - mobile-friendly
5. Good quality - no generation loss during editing

This is a critical architectural decision affecting:
- Recording format (what we capture to)
- Storage format (what we save)
- Playback format (what we decode)
- Export format (what we output)

May need different formats for different stages.","issue":1}

nodes.title: VP9 all-keyframe - WebM compatible, good hardware decode support
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"VP9 with all keyframes:

CONFIG:
```ts
encoder.configure({
  codec: 'vp09.00.10.08',
  width, height,
  bitrate: 8_000_000,
  latencyMode: 'realtime',
})
encoder.encode(frame, { keyFrame: true }) // every frame
```

CHARACTERISTICS:
- WebM container: yes
- WebCodecs: full support
- Hardware decode: Chrome, modern devices
- File size: 5-8x larger than normal VP9
- Decode speed: faster than P-frame chain (~2-3ms vs 6ms)
- Encode speed: moderate

UNKNOWNS:
- Actual decode improvement needs testing
- Mobile hardware decode varies"}

nodes.title: VP8 all-keyframe - WebM compatible, widest hardware support
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"VP8 with all keyframes:

CONFIG:
```ts
encoder.configure({
  codec: 'vp8',
  width, height,
  bitrate: 10_000_000,
})
encoder.encode(frame, { keyFrame: true })
```

CHARACTERISTICS:
- WebM container: yes
- WebCodecs: full support
- Hardware decode: very wide (older devices too)
- File size: larger than VP9 (less efficient codec)
- Decode speed: fast, simple codec
- Encode speed: fast

TRADE-OFF:
- Better compatibility than VP9
- Worse compression than VP9
- Older codec, less optimized"}

nodes.title: AV1 all-keyframe - WebM compatible, best compression, slow encode
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":70,"prompt":"AV1 with all keyframes:

CONFIG:
```ts
encoder.configure({
  codec: 'av01.0.04M.08',
  width, height,
  bitrate: 6_000_000,
})
encoder.encode(frame, { keyFrame: true })
```

CHARACTERISTICS:
- WebM container: yes
- WebCodecs: partial (encode support varies)
- Hardware decode: newer chips only (2020+)
- File size: smallest (best compression)
- Decode speed: moderate
- Encode speed: SLOW (2-10x slower than VP9)

TRADE-OFF:
- Best compression
- But slow encode problematic for real-time recording
- Hardware decode limited to newer devices
- May not be viable for mobile-first app"}

nodes.title: VP9 all-keyframe benchmark: 10% faster decode, 80% fewer slow frames, 4.7x file size
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Benchmark: VP9 normal vs VP9 all-keyframe (4 tracks, 10s playback)

NORMAL VP9 (test-vp9.webm, 1.7MB):
- decode: 6.0ms avg, 28ms max, 1% slow
- bufferAhead: 7.0ms avg, 76ms max

VP9 ALL-KEYFRAME (test-vp9-allkey.webm, 8.0MB):
- decode: 5.4ms avg, 25ms max, 0.2% slow
- bufferAhead: 8.2ms avg, 72ms max

ANALYSIS:
- Decode ~10% faster (no P-frame dependency chain)
- Max spike reduced (28ms → 25ms)
- Slow frames reduced 80% (1% → 0.2%)
- File size 4.7x larger

CONCLUSION:
All-keyframe provides modest decode improvement but NOT transformative.
The 5.4ms per frame is still significant - 4 tracks = 21.6ms total.
Main benefit is reduced variance (fewer spikes).

File size trade-off may not be worth it for mobile-first app.
Better to focus on priority coordination (Options F/H/I) than codec change."}

nodes.title: VideoFrame stride alignment fix: copyTo() packs data densely but constructor expects 128-byte aligned strides. Fix calculates aligned layout for all YUV/RGB formats.
Layout resolver architecture: track-centric slots vs layout-segment-centric placements
Track-centric slots (current): Slot per track with nested segments per clip. Query O(slots × segments), viewport duplicated.
Layout-segment-centric: Segments are periods of stable layout, each with flat placements list. Query O(log n), supports animated layouts.
Key insight: Layout is about space × time, not tracks. Segments should represent periods of stable layout, with flat placement lists for O(log n) query.
Playback workers should be per-clip not per-track - each clip is independent, frames tagged with clipId
Per-stem workers considered but rejected - multiple clips using same stem at different positions need independent buffers
Worker pool needed to reuse PlaybackWorkers across clips - avoids initialization overhead while keeping clips independent
Refactor to clip-based playback workers with worker pool
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"User exploration led to architecture decision:
1. Layout resolver should use segment-based model with flat placements
2. Playback workers should be per-clip (not per-track)
3. Frames tagged with clipId instead of trackId
4. Worker pool to reuse workers and avoid init overhead

Implementation phases:
- Phase 1: Create WorkerPool for playback workers
- Phase 2: Refactor create-player.ts: TrackEntry → ClipEntry, keyed by clipId
- Phase 3: Update playback.worker.ts: tag frames with clipId
- Phase 4: Update compositor.worker.ts: receive frames by clipId
- Phase 5: New layout types + compiler with segment/placement model"}

nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Two-part implementation for prioritizing recording over playback:

Ticket 1: Local decoder backpressure
- Use decoder.decodeQueueSize to skip non-keyframes when decoder is overwhelmed
- No cross-worker coordination needed
- Simple threshold check before each decode

Ticket 2: SAB-based recorder backpressure  
- Muxer broadcasts encoder queue depth via SharedArrayBuffer
- Playback workers check SAB and skip non-keyframes when encoder is busy
- API: createPlaybackScheduler(sab) / createRecordingScheduler(sab)
- SAB passed from main thread to all workers

Combined: skip delta frames if EITHER decoder OR encoder is backed up"}

nodes.title: How to handle overlapping clip layering within a track
Array order = layer order (last in array on top)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"Use clips array order as implicit z-order:
- Last clip in array renders last (on top)
- When recording, append new clip to end
- Reordering = moving clips in array

Pros:
- No schema change
- Simple mental model
- Works out of the box

Cons:
- Reordering affects array structure
- No explicit "layer" concept in UI"}

nodes.title: Add explicit z/layer property to Clip
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"Add optional z-index property to Clip lexicon:

clip: {
  ...existing,
  z: integer  // Higher = on top, default = 0 or array index
}

Pros:
- Explicit control
- Easy to reorder without moving in array
- Future-proof for layer UI

Cons:
- Schema change
- More complexity
- Need to manage z-index values"}

nodes.title: Sort by creation time (TID ordering)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":75,"prompt":"Use clip ID (TID) as implicit ordering:
- Later-created clips have higher TIDs
- Sort clips by ID at compile time
- Most recent recording always on top

Pros:
- No schema change
- Automatic ordering by creation
- TIDs are already unique timestamps

Cons:
- Can't manually reorder
- Ties layer order to creation time forever
- Less intuitive than array order"}

Implement punch-through clip behavior in timeline compiler
Punch-through clip behavior: top clip replaces underlying clips in timeline
Recording from offset with clip layering: append clips, mute track during recording
Split pipeline.ts into audio-elements, create-effect-chain, create-audio-bus modules
Explore VP9 keyframes-only muxing to fix decoder errors during export
Effect system: nested chains with parallel + ref nodes
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Design for effect/signal processing in lexicon:

Core model:
- effect: individual processor (gain, eq, reverb, etc.)
- parallel: splits signal into sub-chains, mixes back with weights
- ref: references a reusable bus by id

Effect chain is array (sequential by default):
[effect, effect, parallel, effect]

Parallel node enables split/merge:
{ type: 'parallel', chains: Effect[][], weights?: number[] }

Ref node enables composition:
{ type: 'ref', bus: string }

Project-level busses for reuse:
busses: { 'verb': [...], 'delay': [...] }

Benefits:
- Linear by default, parallel when needed
- Reusable via refs
- Busses can compose other busses
- Serializable (no circular refs)
- DAW-like routing flexibility"}

nodes.title: Lexicon model: clip/track/group separation
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Three temporospatial primitives with clear separation:

clip (temporal):
- Pure time window into source
- source: stem | track | group
- offset, in, out
- Optional pipeline for effects

track (spatial + timeline):
- Contains clips
- Optional viewport (for absolute positioning)
- Optional pipeline

group (hierarchy + layout):
- Contains tracks | groups (recursive)
- Layout mode: grid | absolute | stack
- Members have blend mode for compositing

Each level can have pipeline: { audio?, video? }
Cascade implicit: clip → track → group → master"}

nodes.title: Signal graph: bus nodes with weighted outputs
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Two-layer architecture separating editing from processing:

Layer 1: Temporospatial (editing)
- clip, track, group define WHAT plays WHERE and WHEN

Layer 2: Signal graph (processing)
- Everything is a bus node: { id, effects, output }
- Outputs are weighted edges: [{ ref: busId, amount: number }]
- Multiple outputs = split/send
- Effects chain within each bus

Bus shape:
{
  type: 'bus',
  id: string,
  effects: Effect[],
  output: { ref: string, amount: number }[]
}

Same model for audio and video:
- Audio: WebAudio routing
- Video: shader chain, framebuffers

Routing is explicit, uniform, graph-shaped."}

nodes.title: Effect chains: parallel + expand for composition
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Effect chains support composition:

effect types:
- Regular effects (gain, eq, blur, glsl, etc.)
- parallel: split signal into sub-chains, mix back with weights
- expand: inline a reusable chain template (macro, not shared)

Chain templates (project-level, for reuse):
chains: {
  'my-eq': [{ type: 'eq' }, { type: 'comp' }]
}

expand = copy-paste inline (each use is independent)
bus routing = shared destination (signals mix)"}

nodes.title: Blend modes: composite concern on group members
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Blend modes are compositing, not signal processing.

Blend mode needs two things: layer AND what's underneath.
Cannot be an effect on a single signal chain.

Lives on group membership:
group: {
  members: [
    { id: 'track1' },
    { id: 'track2', blendMode: 'multiply' },
    { id: 'track3', blendMode: 'screen', opacity: 0.5 },
  ]
}

Why:
- "How does THIS member combine into THIS group"
- Compositor's concern, not signal processing
- Same track could appear in different groups with different blend modes

Separation:
- Effects (processing) → bus graph
- Routing (signal flow) → bus outputs
- Compositing (layer combine) → group members
- Layout (space) → group layout
- Time → clip"}

nodes.title: Routing: explicit send vs route types
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Two operations for connecting to busses:

send: parallel copy, signal continues
{ "type": "send", "ref": "reverb", "amount": 0.3 }

route: final destination, signal ends (always 100%)
{ "type": "route", "ref": "track1-audio" }

Chosen approach: explicit types
- Clearer intent, self-documenting
- Common DAW terminology
- route is obviously terminal
- Prevents dead code mistakes

Alternative considered: passthrough param
{ "ref": "bus", "amount": 0.3, "passthrough": 1 }  // send
{ "ref": "bus", "amount": 1, "passthrough": 0 }    // route
- More flexible (partial passthrough possible)
- But less readable, easier to make mistakes
- Could revisit if we need partial passthrough (0.5)"}

Parallel/expand nodes unnecessary - weighted output arrays create parallelism via graph topology
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Simplification to effect system architecture:

Current design (decisions 145, 148) proposed:
- parallel node: splits signal into sub-chains, mixes back
- expand node: inlines reusable chain templates

Simpler model:
- Pipeline = sequential effects array + outputs array
- outputs: [{ ref: string, amount: number }]
- Parallelism emerges from multiple outputs (split)
- Merging is implicit when multiple pipelines route to same bus

Example:
```ts
pipeline: {
  effects: [gain, eq, comp],  // always sequential
  outputs: [
    { ref: 'reverb', amount: 0.3 },
    { ref: 'delay', amount: 0.2 },
    { ref: 'master', amount: 1.0 }
  ]
}
```

Benefits:
1. No special node types needed (parallel, expand)
2. Matches actual DAW routing model
3. Graph topology = signal flow (what you see is what you get)
4. Reuse via routing to shared buses, not template expansion
5. Simpler lexicon schema"}

nodes.title: send/route distinction unnecessary - implicit in output array structure
Audio vs video parallelism: audio merges implicitly via Web Audio graph, video requires explicit framebuffer compositing
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Asymmetry between audio and video parallel routing:

Audio:
- Web Audio graph handles mixing implicitly
- Multiple inputs to same AudioNode = automatic sum
- Parallelism is "free" - just connect nodes

Video:
- No implicit merge mechanism
- Multiple branches targeting same output need explicit compositing
- Must render each branch to framebuffer, then combine
- Arithmetic for blending (add, multiply, weighted average, etc.) is our responsibility

Implementation implications:
- Audio: weighted outputs just map to Web Audio connections with gain nodes
- Video: need framebuffer management + composition shader for branch merging"}

nodes.title: Implement video effect branch merging with framebuffer compositing
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"Implement explicit branch merging for video effect pipelines:

Requirements:
- Render each branch to intermediate framebuffer
- Composition shader to combine branches with weights
- Support common blend operations (add, multiply, screen, etc.)
- Efficient framebuffer reuse/pooling

Unlike audio where Web Audio handles mixing, video needs manual implementation of the merge step when multiple pipelines output to the same destination."}

nodes.title: Video effects blocked: multi-pass (blur, bloom, glow) - no FBO abstraction
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Multi-pass effects require rendering to intermediate framebuffers then reading back.

Current system compiles to single fragment shader that runs once per pixel.
No render-to-texture capability exists.

Examples blocked: Gaussian blur (separable = 2 passes), bloom, glow, shadows, depth-of-field

Would need:
- Framebuffer Object (FBO) abstraction in VideoCompositor
- renderToTexture(placement): WebGLTexture method
- Pipeline that chains: shader1 → FBO1 → shader2 → FBO2 → canvas"}

nodes.title: Video effects blocked: temporal (motion blur, trails) - no previous frame access
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Temporal effects need access to previous frame's pixel data.

Current system renders each frame independently from single input texture (u_video).
No frame history stored or accessible in shaders.

Examples blocked: Motion blur, trail effects, ghosting, frame averaging, echo

Would need:
- Frame history buffer (ring buffer of N previous frames)
- Additional texture uniforms (u_previousFrame, u_frameHistory[N])
- Memory management for frame retention"}

nodes.title: Video effects blocked: multi-source (displacement, LUTs, masks) - only u_video texture
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Effects sampling multiple sources need additional texture inputs.

Current system only binds one texture: u_video at TEXTURE0.
No mechanism to load secondary textures into effects.

Examples blocked: Displacement maps, lookup tables (color grading LUTs), masks, chromatic aberration with LUT

Would need:
- Effect signature to specify required textures
- Texture binding slots beyond TEXTURE0
- EffectKey expanded to EffectWithInputs type"}

nodes.title: Video effects blocked: cross-placement blend modes - placements render independently
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Advanced blend modes need to read already-rendered pixels.

Current system renders each placement independently with no context of what was already drawn.
Blending done via canvas compositing, not GPU-level.

Examples blocked: Screen, overlay, multiply, color dodge/burn, depth-based blending

Would need:
- Render all placements to FBOs first
- Composition pass that reads multiple FBOs
- GPU blend mode configuration per placement"}

nodes.title: Video effects blocked: geometry transforms (3D rotation, perspective) - fixed quad vertex shader
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"3D/geometry effects need vertex shader flexibility.

Current system uses compile.toQuad() - renders flat quad to viewport.
Effects only work at fragment level, no geometry data available.

Examples blocked: 3D rotation, perspective warp, displacement-based geometry, mesh deformation

Would need:
- Custom vertex shader pipeline
- Geometry/mesh data passed to effects
- compile() with custom vertex shader instead of compile.toQuad()"}

nodes.title: Video effects supported: single-pass per-pixel color transforms with effect chaining
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Current pipeline optimized for color grading:

Supported:
- Per-pixel color transforms (brightness, contrast, saturation, colorize)
- Effect chaining (multiple effects compiled to single shader)
- Effect deduplication (same type used N times → array uniforms)
- Instance-specific parameters (each effect instance has own values)
- Multi-parameter effects (e.g. colorize has vec3 color + float intensity)
- Real-time parameter updates without recompilation

Architecture: effectKeys[] → count types → compile single shader with functions → one GPU pass"}

nodes.title: Video branch merging: compile parallel branches to single shader, not FBOs
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Parallel branches from same source can merge in single fragment shader:

```glsl
// Branches compiled as inline expressions
vec4 branchA = applyBrightness(applyContrast(texColor));
vec4 branchB = applySaturation(applyColorize(texColor));
vec4 merged = branchA * weightA + branchB * weightB;
```

Benefits:
- Single GPU pass, no intermediate textures
- No FBO overhead or memory allocation
- Branches are just code paths in same shader
- Compiler can optimize across branches

FBOs only needed when:
- Branch output feeds another branch's input (serial dependency)
- True multi-pass effects (blur that must read own output)
- Cross-placement compositing (reading already-rendered content)

This simplifies goal 261 - most parallel routing compiles to single program."}

nodes.title: Implement effect pipeline branching with weighted outputs
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Implement branching for effect pipelines using weighted outputs model:

1. Update lexicons - pipeline outputs as array of weighted refs
2. Implement audio branching - Web Audio gain nodes for weighted routing
3. Implement video branching - compile parallel branches to single shader

Based on observations 258, 259, 268: parallelism via graph topology, not special node types."}

Eddy as a suite of apps sharing lexicons/runtime
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Reframing eddy from single app to suite of specialized video editing tools:

- jam.eddy.dj: Mobile, musical collaboration focused (original idea)
- mini.eddy.dj: Swiss army knife of video manipulation, quick transforms
- studio.eddy.dj: Premiere-style desktop editor, multi-track, professional

Architecture enables this:
- Lexicons define portable project format across all apps
- Shared effects/pipelines runtime
- ATProto sync works across all apps

Each app is opinionated about UX but shares the core. "eddy" becomes the ecosystem brand."}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj design: grid-based video sequencer
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"Design direction for jam.eddy.dj - mobile musical video collaboration:

Core concept: Step sequencer meets video compositor
- Rows = tracks/layers (yours or collaborators)
- Columns = beats/moments in time
- Cells = video clips
- Column header = visual layout (how clips composite: grid, pip, split, etc.)

Interactions:
- Tap cell → gallery → select clip
- Drag across row → "paint" clip across columns
- Adaptive grid → adjust precision (fewer/more columns)
- Pinch/edge → extend grid

Prior art: github.com/bigmistqke/pianissimo
- Mobile-first piano roll with similar grid interaction
- Mode-based tools (draw, erase, select, duration)
- Automerge CRDT collaboration
- Adaptive grid for precision control
- Not 1:1 mapping but strong inspiration for touch gestures and grid UX"}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: dual view + per-column duration
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Refined design for jam.eddy.dj:

TWO VIEWS, ONE DATA MODEL:

1. Sequencer View (what plays when)
   - Traditional grid: rows = tracks, columns = time
   - Paint clips, drag to extend
   - Continue vs loop behavior (merged cells vs separate)

2. Layout View (how it looks)  
   - Per-column visual compositor
   - Layout defines cell count: [full]=1, [pip]=2, [2x2]=4, [3-up]=3
   - Assign which tracks go in which slots
   - Each column is its own spatial world

PER-COLUMN DURATION (not global grid):
- Each column has duration: 1 bar, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16
- Narrow columns = fast stutter, wide = sustained moment
- Mix freely - no global grid resolution to manage
- Simpler than pianissimo's adaptive grid approach
- Fits "each column is its own world" model

Column = { layout, duration, slots[] }"}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: orientation-based UI modes
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Three views with PIP preview:

1. Preview - rendered output (can be full-screen or floating PIP)
2. Sequencer - what plays when (tracks × time)
3. Layout - how it looks per column (spatial arrangement)

When in sequencer/layout: preview floats as draggable PIP window

ORIENTATION-BASED UI MODES:

Portrait (content mode):
- Preview-focused, large video display
- Quick edits, playback, record
- One-handed, casual use

Landscape (workspace mode):
- Sequencer/layout focused
- More room for timeline editing
- Preview as sidebar (9:16 fits nicely)
- Two-handed, focused editing

Auto-rotate adapts UI purpose, not just scales it.
No explicit mode toggle - device orientation IS the mode switch."}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: auto-layout for jamming workflow
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":70,"prompt":"JAMMING vs COMPOSING - reducing friction for play-along:

Problem: Full layout control is too much cognitive load when jamming/recording.
You want to focus on performing, not arranging.

Solution direction: Auto-layout option

- Auto-layout ON: system picks layout per column based on active track count
  (1 track = full, 2 = split, 3+ = grid, etc.)
- Auto-layout OFF: manual control per column

Could be:
- Global toggle (auto-layout on/off)
- Per-column lock (🔒 locked keeps layout, 🔓 unlocked auto-adjusts)
- Or both - global default + per-column override

Core insight: jamming needs less friction, composing needs more control.
Move fluidly between them - jam first with auto, refine later with manual.

Still fuzzy on exact UX - open design question."}

nodes.title: Implement jam.eddy.dj - Grid-Based Video Sequencer
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Implement the following plan:

# Implement jam.eddy.dj - Grid-Based Video Sequencer

**Goal:** Create a mobile-first collaborative video sequencer app with grid-based composition.

## Overview

jam.eddy.dj is a new app in the eddy suite - a 4-track-inspired video sequencer for musical collaboration.

**Core Concepts:**
- Columns = time segments (variable duration per column: 1 bar, 1/2, 1/4, etc.)
- Rows/Tracks = layers of video clips
- Layout per column = spatial arrangement (full, pip, 2x2, 3-up, etc.)
- Auto-layout option for jamming (manual control for composing)

**Three Views:**
1. **Preview** - rendered output (full-screen or floating PIP)
2. **Sequencer** - what plays when (tracks × columns grid, paint clips)
3. **Layout** - how it looks per column (spatial arrangement)

**Orientation-Based UI:**
- Portrait = content mode (preview-focused, playback, record)
- Landscape = workspace mode (sequencer/layout editing)"}

Package structure for compositor/playback extraction
Option A: Expand @eddy/video with compositor engine
Option B: New @eddy/compositor package
Option C: New @eddy/runtime package
Option D: Keep in apps, share via copy/adapt
Option A tradeoffs: Keeps video-related code together, but @eddy/video becomes heavier. May conflate low-level WebGL with high-level orchestration.
Option B tradeoffs: Clear separation - @eddy/video stays low-level, @eddy/compositor handles orchestration. But adds another package.
Option C tradeoffs: Generic name, could include both compositor and playback. But 'runtime' is vague.
Option D tradeoffs: Simplest short-term, but leads to duplication. jam.eddy.dj would copy/adapt from app.
Naming decision: makeVideoCompositor (low-level WebGL) + makeVideoRenderer (high-level orchestration from compositor.worker.ts)
Committed: feat: extract @eddy/solid package with shared SolidJS primitives
Naming correction: makeVideoRenderer is the WebGL layer (current compositor.ts → make-video-renderer.ts), makeVideoCompositor is the orchestration logic from compositor.worker.ts (minus worker RPC)
Extract makeVideoRenderer and makeVideoCompositor from compositor.ts and compositor.worker.ts
Extracted makeVideoRenderer (WebGL) and makeVideoCompositor (orchestration) - worker reduced from 550 to 210 lines
Committed: refactor - extract makeVideoRenderer and makeVideoCompositor
Committed: refactor - revert library packages to src entries, remove tsup build
FBO compositing needed for advanced multi-pass video effects
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Future consideration: Framebuffer compositing will be needed for:
- Serial dependencies (branch output feeds another branch's input)
- True multi-pass effects (blur that must read own output)
- Cross-placement compositing (reading already-rendered content)

Current single-shader compilation handles most parallel routing cases.
FBO approach is more complex but enables effects that can't be expressed in one pass."}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: clips flow through layouts, not bound to columns
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Key design clarification: Clips are independent of columns.

- A track's clip can play continuously across multiple columns
- Columns are "layout keyframes" - moments where spatial arrangement changes
- The clip keeps playing while the layout morphs around it

Example: A clip spanning columns 1-4 smoothly transitions through each column's layout as playback progresses.

This separates "what plays" (clip layer) from "how it looks" (layout layer)."}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: grid-snapped clips for mobile UX
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Design decision: Clips snap to column boundaries (not free-flowing).

Rationale:
- Mobile-first: touch-friendly interactions (tap/drag cells)
- No precision edge-dragging needed
- Variable column duration (1 bar, 1/2, 1/4, etc.) still provides timing flexibility
- Narrow columns = quick moments, wide columns = sustained

A clip spanning columns 2-5:
- Starts at column 2's start time
- Ends at column 5's end time
- Transitions through each column's layout

Grid snapping keeps the "clips flow through layouts" concept while simplifying interaction."}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: uses existing lexicon, columns are UI layer
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Design decision: jam.eddy.dj uses the same Project/Track/Clip/Group lexicon as eddy.dj.

Track/Clip model (from existing lexicon):
- Track contains Clips in sequence (only one plays at a time)
- Clips can contain Groups with nested Track references
- Same hierarchy: <track><clip><group><track id="1"/></group></clip>...</track>

Columns are a UI concept layered on top:
1. Define time segment boundaries (where clip edges snap)
2. Layout keyframes (spatial arrangement changes)

jam.eddy.dj is a different UI paradigm (grid-based) for the same underlying data model, not a new data model."}

nodes.title: jam.eddy.dj: two independent layers (clip + layout)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Architecture insight: jam.eddy.dj has two independent layers.

1. CLIP LAYER - what plays when
   - Tracks with clips that span columns (grid-snapped)
   - Clips play continuously, independent of layout changes
   - Sequencer View edits this layer

2. LAYOUT LAYER - how it looks
   - Columns as "layout keyframes" defining spatial arrangement
   - Each column: layout type (full/pip/2x2) + slot assignments
   - Layout View edits this layer

At render time:
- Find current column at time T
- Get active tracks for that column
- Render according to column's layout
- Clips transition smoothly through layouts

The interweaving: clips flow through changing layouts as time progresses."}

Implemented video pipeline for Preview component using makeVideoCompositor and makeVideoPlayback with UrlSource

mediabunny UrlSource could potentially stream directly from PDS blob endpoints, eliminating OPFS storage. Requires PDS to support: 1) Range requests (HTTP 206) for seeking, 2) CORS headers. Would simplify architecture significantly - no upload step, instant playback.

AT Protocol 'not supported' for direct blob serving is about SECURITY, not technical capability. Core issue: same-origin XSS attacks - if app fetches blobs directly from PDS, malicious user-uploaded content (SVG with scripts, HTML) could execute with access to app's cookies/storage.

AT Protocol recommended blob architecture: Browser → CDN/Proxy → PDS getBlob. Proxy layer provides: 1) separate origin isolation, 2) CSP headers (default-src 'none'; sandbox), 3) content sanitization, 4) sandboxed media transcoding. OPFS approach sidesteps this by downloading to isolated local storage.

UrlSource direct-from-PDS tradeoff: technically possible but security risk for untrusted content. For personal/experimental apps with controlled content - acceptable. For production with user-uploaded content - need proxy layer. getBlob doesn't require auth (blobs are public), CORS depends on PDS implementation, Range request support unknown.
